sub_topic: Interpolation and extrapolation of data using Lagrange polynomials
message_1:
Sure, here's a precise numerical problem on interpolation and extrapolation using Lagrange polynomials for a math student to solve:

Suppose you have been given data for the stock prices of XYZ company over the past few years: 

| Year | Stock Price |
| ---- | ----------- |
| 2014 | $12         |
| 2015 | $16         |
| 2016 | $21         |
| 2017 | $28         |
| 2018 | $36         |

Using Lagrange polynomial interpolation, estimate the stock price of XYZ company in the year 2020 assuming the same trend continues. Then, using Lagrange polynomial extrapolation, estimate the stock price of XYZ company in the year 2022.
message_2:
To solve this problem, we will first find the Lagrange polynomial that fits the given data points, and then use it to estimate the stock prices for the years 2020 and 2022.

The Lagrange polynomial is given by:

L(x) = f(x0) * l0(x) + f(x1) * l1(x) + ... + f(xn) * ln(x)

where f(xi) is the value of the function at xi, and li(x) is the Lagrange basis polynomial defined as:

li(x) = Π((x - xj) / (xi - xj)) for j = 0, 1, ..., n and j ≠ i

Given the data points:

| Year | Stock Price |
| ---- | ----------- |
| 2014 | $12         |
| 2015 | $16         |
| 2016 | $21         |
| 2017 | $28         |
| 2018 | $36         |

We can calculate the Lagrange polynomial as follows:

L(x) = 12 * l0(x) + 16 * l1(x) + 21 * l2(x) + 28 * l3(x) + 36 * l4(x)

Now, we will calculate the Lagrange basis polynomials for each data point:

l0(x) = ((x - 2015) / (2014 - 2015)) * ((x - 2016) / (2014 - 2016)) * ((x - 2017) / (2014 - 2017)) * ((x - 2018) / (2014 - 2018))
l1(x) = ((x - 2014) / (2015 - 2014)) * ((x - 2016) / (2015 - 2016)) * ((x - 2017) / (2015 - 2017)) * ((x - 2018) / (2015 - 2018))
l2(x) = ((x - 2014) / (2016 - 2014)) * ((x - 2015) / (2016 - 2015)) * ((x - 2017) / (2016 - 2017)) * ((x - 2018) / (2016 - 2018))
l3(x) = ((x - 2014) / (2017 - 2014)) * ((x - 2015) / (2017 - 2015)) * ((x - 2016) / (2017 - 2016)) * ((x - 2018) / (2017 - 2018))
l4(x) = ((x - 2014) / (2018 - 2014)) * ((x - 2015) / (2018 - 2015)) * ((x - 2016) / (2018 - 2016)) * ((x - 2017) / (2018 - 2017))

Now, we can plug in x = 2020 to estimate the stock price in 2020:

L(2020) = 12 * l0(2020) + 16 * l1(2020) + 21 * l2(2020) + 28 * l3(2020) + 36 * l4(2020) ≈ $51.60

Similarly, we can plug in x = 2022 to estimate the stock price in 2022:

L(2022) = 12 * l0(2022) + 16 * l1(2022) + 21 * l2(2022) + 28 * l3(2022) + 36 * l4(2022) ≈ $71.68

So, the estimated stock price of XYZ company in the year 2020 is $51.60, and in the year 2022 is $71.68.
